results.title: Arctic jungle
results.creator_credit: Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
The life of the Eskimo is a constant struggle for existence against the harshness of the Arctic environment. The film shows spear fishing, making lamp fuel, manufacturing clothing and kayaks, and hunting powerful quarry like the polar bear and white whale.

results.title: Canada

results.title: Cattle country
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada”.
The soil of the foothills of the Rocky Mountains (North America) is ideal for pasture, and the climate is excellently suited to cattle-raising. Modern methods of protecting cattle during winter, how they are treated for warble-fly, methods of breeding, spring migration to fresh grazing lands, mustering for market, and shipping away for sale, are studied on this film of Canadian cattle raising. No credits available.

results.title: Can You Avoid Cancer?
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: The Food Connection (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Can You Avoid Cancer?”.
Some major cancers seem to follow the Western way of life, and many surprising clues point towards our food The members of a family look at their typical eating habits and try some changes which could keep them healthier.

results.title: Work and play (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Can You Avoid Cancer?”.
What are the risks of getting cancer from substances you breathe in or handle at work? Or from air pollution? Or from sitting in the sun? This program looks at the links between cancer and industry, and suggests some steps for preventing even more cancer deaths in the future

results.title: Loading the Dice(TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Can You Avoid Cancer?”.
This series aims to promote a better understanding of what cancer is and to develop a more hopeful and less emotional attitude to the disease. This program answers common questions and looks at the reasons why epidemiology could hold the clues to possible prevention.

group_works.title: The Role of the Supreme Court

results.title: The Role of the Supreme Court
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
Dr David Fellman claims that the U.S. Supreme Court is unique because of its great power. The American system of government is based on the constitution and the Supreme Court is its final judge and arbiter. Dr Fellman discusses the role, organisation, jurisdiction procedures of the supreme court, and explains how it fits in with other U.S. Governmental and civil institutions

group_siblings.title: How our two party system operates
Pressure groups in action
group_siblings.creator_credit: Marbury Ogle, Cinecraft Productions and Republic Steel Corporation

results.title: Pressure groups in action
results.creator_credit: Marbury Ogle, Cinecraft Productions and Republic Steel Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
Dr Marbury Ogle says that man has always organised groups to help him achieve what was beyond the capacity of one person. In America there are at least 300,000 formal and informal pressure groups, which try to direct, educate and motivate members, to win over the general public and to try to influence the government by lobbying. The lobbyist may act as a valuable informal consultant to a politician while his group may give minorities a chance to express their needs.
